newsitem.title: SLOVAKIA: Slovak FinMin says revenue may shrink in H2 96.
newsitem.headline: Slovak FinMin says revenue may shrink in H2 96.

text.p: Finance Minister Sergej Kozlik told parliament on Wednesday the first-half 1996 budget deficit of 6.13 billion crowns was satisfactory, but the flow of revenue may tighten later in the year.
Last month the ministry reported first-half revenue of 79.5 billion crowns and spending of 85.7 billion, representing 49 percent and 45.2 percent respectively of the full 1996 budget.

"These results are satisfactory with regard to the deficit," Kozlik told the house. The full 1996 budget deficit was forecast at 27 billion crowns, with revenues expected to total 162.4 billion crowns and expenditures 189.4 billion.
Kozlik did not offer a revised forecast for the budget for the full year.
He said the biggest shortfall on expected revenues in the first half of the year was in value-added tax, about 6.4 billion crowns, and sales tax, representing around 2.3 billion crowns.
"From this point of view, the development of the growth of the budget income will be tight in the second half of the year," Kozlik said.
He said if the negative tendencies in tax revenue continued in the second half of the year, the shortfall on these revenues alone could total some 10 billion crowns.
